description.div: Introduction to the sociological study of human behavior, especially social organization, culture, and the social institutions that comprise society. Attention to social change, differentiation and inequality, and other social issues.

notes.div: Required for Great Plains Studies majors and minors.

description.div: Interdisciplinary study of the natural environment, social environment, human heritage, arts and humanities of the Great Plains.

notes.div: Requires enrollment in the GreatPlains Studies majors and minors

description.div: Topic varies.

prerequisite.div: SOCI 182.

notes.div: Requires enrollment in the Alpha Learning Community Program.

description.div: Topic varies.

prerequisite.div: Admission to the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program.

description.div: Topics vary.
Wide range of different topics at the undergraduate level.
Interdisciplinary examination of the contributions of women to society and societal attitudes toward women. Roles and values of women in contemporary society. Lecture, discussion, special problems.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Treatment of the principal "problem" areas in contemporary society. Analysis of processes of disorganization in society, with attention to contrasting processes by which social structures are formed and perpetuated.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

notes.div: SOCI 205 and CRIM 251 cannot both be applied toward the degree in arts and sciences.

description.div: Introduction to the techniques of collecting and analyzing data and techniques of research reporting. Emphasis on interpretation and evaluation of sociological research.

prerequisite.div: SOCI 205.

description.div: Practical exercises in the actual conduct of sociological research projects. Emphasis on training and development of skills, techniques, and methods of data analysis, and interpretation of findings in light of sociological theories.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

notes.div: CRIM 335 and SOCI 209 cannot both be applied toward the degree.

description.div: Introduction to the sociological approach to the study of crime, including the definition of crime, approaches to its measurement, and the major theories of crime. Social institutions intended to prevent or correct criminal behavior.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Concepts of race and patterns of race distribution. Impact of European expansion on ethnic relations. Types of ethnic social systems. Patterns of ethnic social interaction. Problems of minorities. Types of ethnic policies.

Introduction to one of the largest minority groups in the United States-Chicanos (Mexican Americans). Primary consideration given to the history and present status of Chicanos with emphasis on their interaction with various social institutions.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Historic marriage and family patterns. American family, past and present. Husband-wife relationships. Parent-child relationships. Family-society relationships.

prerequisite.div: Open to second semester freshmen and above.

description.div: The rural environment and its people; its groups and associations; and its social institutions.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Rise of the modern city; patterns of urban growth; demographic, distributive, ecological aspects of the city; institutional and regional tendencies and problems; urban-regional planning.

notes.div: Core course for minors in conflict and conflict resolution

description.div: Introduction to the study of the biological, economic, political-historical, and cultural bases of war and group conflict.

prerequisite.div: Prereq: 3 hrs of sociology or related social sciences

description.div: Introduction to the sociological study of mass media, including the social construction of gender, race, class, and politics.Â Explores audience interaction with media texts. Emphasis on analytical skills for media literacy.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Historical and contemporary patterns of drug use. Analysis of the antecedents and consequences of various forms of drug abuse. Examination of the types and effectiveness of legal responses to specific classes of drugs including; prohibition, decriminalization, and legalization. Prevention and treatment approaches to drug use.

prerequisite.div: SOCI 101 and 205, or permission.

notes.div: SOCI 206 recommended.

description.div: Research methods organized around an applied research project. Conduct research in an applied setting, preparation of interview schedules, problem definition, review of research techniques, and research design and measurement.

prerequisite.div: SOCI 310A.

notes.div: SOCI 206 recommended.

description.div: Continuation of SOCI 310A.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

notes.div: CRIM 337 and SOCI 311 cannot both be applied toward the degree.

description.div: Nature and extent of juvenile delinquency, considered in relation to the role of adolescents in modern society. Includes a review of the methods used to study delinquency, theories of delinquency, social influences on delinquent behavior, and the nature of the juvenile justice system.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs of sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Social, cultural, political, and economic aspects of sport as a social institution. Gender, race, and social class issues related to sport.

notes.div: Intensive writing activity leading to a social research paper

description.div: Survey of 19th and 20th century writers whose ideas have had a strong impact on the development of contemporary sociology and sociological theory, ranging from Karl Marx, Max Weber and Emile Durkheim to W.E.B. DuBois, Patricia Hill Collins and Harold Garfinkle.

course.title: Ethics and the Responsible Conduct of Research

prerequisite.div: 6 hours of social and/or biological sciences.

description.div: Ethical decision making in research. Comprehensive review of the responsible conduct of research. Identify, define, and analyze ethical issues in the conduct of human subject research. Study civic responsibility and stewardship in the context of the responsible conduct of research. Examine emergent areas of human subjects in an increasingly interdisciplinary research environment.

prerequisite.div: Major or minor in sociology; SOCI 205 and 206; SOCI 355 or 455; and permission.

description.div: Participation in a research project under the supervision of an experienced researcher in the Department of Sociology, the Bureau of Sociological Research, or a public agency or private enterprise (e.g., the Gallup Organization) engaged in sociological research.

prerequisite.div: Sociology major or minor, 9 hrs sociology, and permission.

notes.div: Students should see chief undergraduate adviser for details.

description.div: Field work in public or other organizations.

prerequisite.div: As announced by department.

description.div: Wide range of different topics at the undergraduate level.

prerequisite.div: Open to seniors and especially qualified juniors, with permission.

description.div: Special readings on selected topics; investigations in library or field.

prerequisite.div: Open to candidates for degrees with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the College of Arts and Sciences and to seniors and especially qualified juniors, with permission.

description.div: Special readings on selected topics; investigations in library or field.

course.title: Strategies of Social Research: Qualitative Methods

description.div: Systematic review and application of qualitative research methods, including participant observation, unstructured interviewing, audiovisual techniques and personal document analysis; data collection and interpretation emphasized as well as different theoretical assumptions underlying their various approaches.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Analysis of sociological principles of social change at both the community and primary group level; analysis of research and theoretical literature.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences

description.div: Contemporary issues confronting American families and family research. Adolescent pregnancy, work-family policy, family violence, divorce, single parents, and step families.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Analysis of the structure and effects of the media of mass communication.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Psychosocial bases of group behavior, inter-stimulation, and behavioral products.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Personality and the sociocultural environment.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Historical and cross-cultural approach to population issues by linking changes in fertility and mortality to social institutions. Focuses on the link between population processes and such issues as gender roles, the role of the family, the Third World, and poverty and inequality.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Trends in urbanization that incorporate demography, ecology, and planning. Selected urban problems.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences or permission.

description.div: Role of humans in the ecosystem, especially the interaction of human societies with the natural environment, including other species and other human societies. Theories of the sociocultural causes of environmentally-related problems and the policies designed to deal with these problems.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Analyzes diversity in family structure and family choices. Includes: rural families, gay/lesbian families, Native American families, African American families, Latino families, working class and working poor families and cohabitation.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Contemporary theory and research dealing with family structure and change. Focuses on family systems that characterize different social classes and various ethnic groups in our society. Selected problems and contemporary research emphasized.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Analysis of means of social control, with emphasis upon social institutions.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Consideration of sources and nature of religion, drawing on contributions of anthropologists, sociologists, psychologists, and others. Emphasis on interaction of religion and society.

course.title: Sociology of Health and Health Professions

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Social and cultural bases of health and illness. Social factors in the definition of illness and in the organization and distribution of health care.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social science.

description.div: Survey of the nineteenth- and early twentieth-century writers whose ideas have had a strong impact on the development of contemporary sociology and sociological theories. Emphasis on the work of such persons as Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim, Max Weber, George Herbert Mead, and Georg Simmel.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Analysis of education as a social institution and its relationship to other institutions, e.g., economy, polity, religion, and the family. Emphasizes the role of the educational institution as an agent of stability and change. Emphasis on research and policy evaluation.

prerequisite.div: SOCI 101, 205, and 206; and permission.

description.div: The logic and design of sociological research: the nature of science and logic of social inquiry; epistemic relations; design of research problems; data collection techniques and sampling.

course.title: Quantitative Methods of Social Research I

prerequisite.div: SOCI 101, 205, and 206; and permission.

description.div: The logic and techniques of sociological analysis: techniques of scaling and index construction; contingency table analysis; measures of association; parametric and nonparametric statistical inference; and generalizations from systematic findings.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: The conceptual structures of selected theorists and of the basis of theory construction and testing.

prerequisite.div: For SOCI 465: SOCI 205 and 206.

notes.div: For SOCI 865: None.

description.div: Basic issues related to the design and analysis of sample surveys. The basics of questionnaire construction, sampling, data collection, analysis and data presentation.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing and permission.

notes.div: Open to students with an interest in international relations.

description.div: Topic varies

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs social sciences.

description.div: Techniques useful for research aiding in policy making and for assessing the impact of policy. Acquaints student with the role of research in policy formation and evaluation and to give the student experience in conducting such research.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Presentation of frameworks for occupations and professions; analysis of occupational structure and mobility in American society and its relation to adult socialization and career development; occupational and professional associations and society.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing and 12 hrs in one of the departments in which the course is listed.

notes.div: Open to advanced students planning careers in the professions in which knowledge of human behavior and society is important (e.g., helping professions, medicine, law, ministry, education, etc.).

description.div: Interdisciplinary approach to the study of human sexuality in terms of the psychological, social, cultural, anthropological, legal, historical, and physical characteristics of individual sexuality and sex in society.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

notes.div: CRIM 413 and SOCI 474 cannot both be applied toward the degree.

description.div: Theory and empirical research on conformity and deviance. Survey of the development of scholarly thinking on the nature and sources of deviance, societal reactions to deviance, and processes of social control.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing or permission.

notes.div: Capstone course.

description.div: Holistic approach to the selection and analysis of planning strategies for protecting water quality from nonpoint sources of contamination. Introduction to the use of methods of analyzing the impact of strategies on whole systems and subsystems; for selecting strategies; and for evaluating present strategies.

courseCode.subject: HIST
courseCode.courseGroup: Latin American, Asian, Middle Eastern or African History

courseCode.subject: HIST
courseCode.courseGroup: Latin American, Asian, Middle Eastern or African History

prerequisite.div: Junior standing and permission.

notes.div: Topical seminar required for all Latin American Studies majors.

description.div: An interdisciplinary analysis of topical issues in Latin American Studies.

course.title: Social Inequality: Stratification and Life Chances

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Structured inequalities, including social class, race/ethnicity, gender and age stratification. The intersections of these as institutionalized inequalities examined for their causes and effects on individuals and groups. Emphasis on the role of social power, economic resources and occupational structures in the nature of inequality and social mobility in the United States.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Systematic examination of racial, ethnic, and other minority groups. History and present status of such groups, the origins of prejudice and discrimination, and the application of social science knowledge toward the elimination of minority group problems.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs social sciences.

notes.div: SOCI 200 is strongly recommended.

description.div: Evaluation and application of scholarly theory and research on women in their societal context. The nature and effects of sex stratification, gendered culture, institutionalized sexism, feminist theory and sociology of knowledge.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs sociology or related social sciences.

description.div: Application of sociological analysis to the problem of power; power structures and elite formation as they relate to democratic society and political extremism.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; sociology major.

notes.div: It is recommended that SOCI 205, 206, and 455 be completed prior to taking the SOCI 495.

description.div: A senior-level overview of the discipline of sociology, including theory, methods, and substantive areas. Current monographs critically analyzed. The development of sociology, new directions in the discipline, and careers for sociologists.

course.title: Special Topics in Crime, Deviance, and Social Control

prerequisite.div: Varies.

notes.div: See course description or registration guide. Topic for the term announced prior to early registration.

description.div: Variety of topics in crime, deviance, and social control.

prerequisite.div: Varies.

notes.div: See course description or registration guide. Topic for the term announced prior to early registration.

description.div: Wide variety of different topics.

Effects of various data collection methods on survey errors. The strengths, weaknesses, and challenges of data collection modes and mixed-mode methods. Processes underlying data collection and practical challenges that arise with each mode; coverage error; nonresponse error; interviewer effects and training; timing; and mode effects.

Design of probability samples, sampling populations of humans and unique challenges posed by such populations, restricted by cost and available sampling frames. Simple random sampling, stratification, cluster sampling, systematic sampling, multistage sampling, and probability proportional to size sampling, area probability sampling, and telephone samples.

prerequisite.div: Permission

description.div: Opportunity to apply concepts and methods in field setting and to obtain experience that will be valuable preparation for professional assignments in research, policy analysis, and administration.

prerequisite.div: Admission to masters degree program and permission of major adviser
Permission
Permission
Permission
Permission

course.title: Seminar in Stratification, Class, and Inequality

prerequisite.div: Permission
Permission
Permission
Permission

description.div: Design of questionnaires for survey research and the theoretical and practical issues arising from them. Selection of appropriate measurement techniques for assessing opinions, past behaviors and events, and factual material.

P/N only. Professional development for careers in college teaching and research in sociology.
A. Teaching (1 cr)
B. Graduate Study and Career Research (1 cr)
D. Publications (1 cr)

prerequisite.div: Permission
Permission
Admission to doctoral degree program and permission of supervisory committee chair
